urn:contentItem:5KRW-JXV1-DY0W-40Y8-00000-00Trusting Real Estate; Down Payment Debate; Do You Trust Technology?; School System Skepticism; America's Trust Deficit; Businesses Leery of2015-05-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:41ZLexisNexisTrusting Real Estate; Down Payment Debate; Do You Trust Technology?; School System Skepticism; America's Trust Deficit; Businesses Leery ofLanhamFULL TEXT

(OPENING MUSIC - "CAVUTO")

NEIL CAVUTO, HOST: Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto.

And America, we have a problem - a trust problem.

Right now, across the nation, we're seeing a loss of faith in all our institutions among all political types.

Investors burned by the financial crash staying out of the stock market. Home buyers singed by the real estate meltdown staying out of the housing market. A generation of kids exposed to both showing little interest in either. Their trust in institutions down. Their faith in marriage itself at an all-time low. Parents who've lost confidence at a public school system that fails their kids despite the government pouring billions of dollars into a system that fails to raise their test scores.

Now, it would be one thing if the media pounced on government's clear failures but more inclined to stay in government's hip pocket, convinced that the government isn't the problem, how much we are giving it is.

So a collective media call to doubledown on the spending that has yet to work. A weird trust in repeating the same mistakes only this time, with pricier mistakes and desperately hoping for a different result.

So you needn't be Einstein to figure that I'm right or left. This is just stupid - just an average American taxpayer whose gut says this has got to stop.

So tonight, we stop and we step back - way back. We're going to get to the bottom of why America keeps coming up short and it keeps coming back to trust.

So we've decided to give this issue (INAUDIBLE) the whole show because this isn't about the spending deficit or real estate deficit or a market deficit or faith deficit. This, my friends, is about America's trust deficit.

We begin with Washington's deficit.

Taxpayers are seeing lots of their tax money spent but what are they getting for all that spending? Now, more than half of Americans think that more government means more problems.

Steve Moore says taxpayers are tired of Washington spending (INAUDIBLE) after bad. Lizzie MacDonald says that at least the coverage of that isn't getting the proper coverage. And Basil Smikle says right now, this taxpayer trust is something that both parties need to address.

All right. So, Steve, first to you. How bad is this?

STEVE MOORE, HERITAGE FOUNDATION VISITING FELLOW: Well, it's really bad. I mean, I was thinking, Neil, when you asked me to do this show about how much Washington has changed in just the last 25 or 30 years I've been here. When I came to Washington, the federal government was spending about a trillion dollars. Now, Neil, it's going to - next year, it'll be spending $4 trillion. And even adjusted for inflation, that's more than doubling up the cost of government. And then you ask people, "Do you think government is better today than it was 30 or 40 years ago?" And people say, "I don't know." One other example, if I may, Neil, you mentioned schools. If you look at what's happened to per capita spending per pupil spending in the schools versus - let's say - the 1950s or 60s when schools were a lot better, we're spending about three times as much as we used to. So I think people are saying, "Wait a minute." Throwing more money at these problems as a lot of liberals (INAUDIBLE) after what happened in Baltimore if we just spent more money, people are saying, "You're crazy. That's the source of the problem. It's not going to solve the crisis."

CAVUTO: What do you think, Liz?

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: Well, I think Steve is exactly right and as for one, the media doesn't really cover it correctly. John (INAUDIBLE), the economist put out a great story and here's the thing, Neil. When the government spends money, that is added to GDP. So when the government doesn't spend money, politicians are afraid, "Oh, GDP is going to go down." So you could see the vicious circle that's in there. Also, we do have severe crony capitalism, of course. Watch this. Inspector General who oversees Medicare said, "Hey, wait a second." Medicare is not even negotiating drug rebates with drug manufacturers while Medicaid is. And so why? Because their laws written there says, "You know what? You're not allowed to - you can't interfere with the negotiation between drug companies and the federal government." What is that about? I'm not sure.

CAVUTO: What's even more alarming to me is when you talk to kids of all political stripes, party-affiliation, it's (INAUDIBLE) maybe it's just their blaming it on the parents or blaming it on the prior generations. They have an inherent distrust of Washington, an inherent distrust of institutions, an inherent distrust of any one of authority to get anything done.

BASIL SMIKLE, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: They do and that's unfortunate. Look, I am a person that doesn't necessarily believe that government is the answer to all of our problems but there is a sort of minimum that I think government sets where the (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Well, have we gone beyond the minimum?

SMIKLE: I don't think we've gone beyond the minimum but I think we've - there may be sort of a dearth of ideas. I think we need some better ideas, some (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: But to Lizzie's point, do you think the dearth of ideas is that we just go back to the same old idea? (INAUDIBLE).

SMIKLE: Listen, Neil, (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Let him finish.

SMIKLE: I go back to - I go back to a point when David Dinkins was mayor of New York City and asked the state to increase taxes to put more cops on the street. It was during his administration that you started to see a decline in crime here in New York City and a lot of it is pegged to an increase in taxation. So when I think when (INAUDIBLE) legislators (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Weird that you would mention David Dinkins, although with the present mayor, now Dinkins looks like Winston Churchill.

SMIKLE: Listen, it started - it started during his administration. Giuliani takes credit for it but that's OK. But.

CAVUTO: All right. Well, that's (INAUDIBLE).

SMIKLE: --the thing is if you point - if you point directly to the expenditure and the outcome then I think you will think (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Well, but Steve, my big fear with this is that we're going to go back to the same well and say, "Well, more money" or maybe we get a better idea how to spend that money better, but it's always going to be more, more, more. That's what worries me.

MOORE: Yes. I think the problem with this analysis that "Gee, if we only had more government", I think that the problem is this, Neil, that the government has gotten away from the core functions that it is supposed to do. It's supposed to educate our kids. It's supposed to build good roads and highways. It's supposed to defend us. It's not to allow things like what happened in Benghazi. And I would simply respond to this point that the government's not doing much. I think the reason the government is failing in the fundamental things it's supposed to be doing is because it's doing too much. I mean, a good example of this with young people because these polls show that young people are the ones who have lost the most confidence in government. And when I talk to my kids who are completely non-ideological - they don't listen to any of this political stuff. But you know what they don't get? They don't get how the federal government can't run a website for the healthcare system. They're like, "Wait a minute. A seventh-grader can do that."

MACDONALD: Yes. But we're (INAUDIBLE). But the thing is - here's the thing. Why raise taxes when the government is wasting so much money? More than a trillion dollars.

MOORE: Right, exactly.

MACDONALD: --worth of vacant federal office buildings littering the landscape. $200 billion in overlap and duplication in the federal government. And you have an incompetent health reform website that is just sucking up money right and left, that is really not working and it's all loaded on Medicaid whose budget is getting blown out right there.

SMIKLE: Yes, we're talking about - I mean, we don't need to be talking about a website here. What I think we need to be talking about are how government can help - help - solve problems but not be the conclusion. And even the president has said that.

CAVUTO: But think about (INAUDIBLE) - but why do you think that right after Baltimore, the immediate inclination was "We need more money", "We need more money", "We need more money." Baltimore in a per capita on a per student basis gets almost as much money as New York City students do. Number two to them. Neither are exactly breaking the mental walls down. So why is there a feeling that if in doubt, throw more money at it?

SMIKLE: Well, it's not the fact that you're throwing more money at it. It's how that money gets spent. And if you're - if you're - but if you're questioning (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: But they're not even fine-tuning it. They're saying it (INAUDIBLE) a matter they haven't (INAUDIBLE) enough money.

SMIKLE: I think it's important to be able to track where that money goes and make sure the outcomes.

CAVUTO: But they don't. They don't.

SMIKLE: --make sure the outcomes (INAUDIBLE). No, I think that's happening. That happened here in New York. It's happening in many other cities where you can actually see that additional.

CAVUTO: We spent trillions on a war on poverty and all that has yet to move the poverty needle.

SMIKLE: I think it's moved the needle quite significantly. But what.

CAVUTO: Three percent. Three percent.

SMIKLE: --but that's significant. What I do think is problematic though.

MACDONALD: It is?

CAVUTO: (INAUDIBLE) trillion dollars?

SMIKLE: If you talk to the people who came who.

MACDONALD: Three percent since the 60s? (INAUDIBLE).

SMIKLE: --(INAUDIBLE) - if you - if you talk about the people who came out of poverty, that's significant for them.

MACDONALD: Listen, we all - right. But we all want to help the poor. You know what helps the poor is a job, because then they become emotionally and literally invested in their area. They don't want to destroy their job or destroy the area around them.

CAVUTO: Well, do you think that's it? The trust - we don't trust the government to know that? Whether you like it or not, we don't trust them to do the right thing.

MACDONALD: We know we don't trust them because we've thrown so much money out already and it hasn't really worked.

SMIKLE: But I don't think - I also don't think that they're - I also don't think that anyone - whether either Democratic side or the Republican side, you all speak for that - but I certainly don't think any Democrat is saying, "Just throw money at the problem." That is not the solution. (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Actually, last week, they were. But by the way, (INAUDIBLE). You're right to say that both parties have failed in this regard because they do think even Republicans with defense, "Throw more money out. Throw more money out." But, Steve, what do you think of that - where we stand with the trust issue because when it comes to government, we don't stand too well here.

MOORE: Well, we don't. And I'll just give you one example of what you guys were talking about. I just had a piece in the "Wall Street Journal" this week about how we've got a D.C. voucher program that is educating kids in inner cities by allowing them to go in other schools. And here's the amazing thing about that program. It is educating kids, Neil, giving them a quality education for one-half of what it costs in the public schools and we can't get the liberals to support the program and it's helping a lot of kids.

CAVUTO: Well, there are lot of - there are a lot of players not measuring up here.

But, guys, I want to thank you all. (INAUDIBLE). You do this very, very well.

In the meantime, fastfood giant Andy Puzder says businesses shouldn't trust Washington either and either Republicans offering them help or Democrats because tax bills, red tape just seem to pile up and Uncle Sam just keeps piling on.

So Andy, how do you get businesses to believe that Washington has their back. 'Cause you've argued for many years now, they have a sense that it does not.

ANDY PUZDER, HARDEE'S & CARL'S JR CEO: Well, it did help in 2010 when the Republicans took over the House and then again in '12 when they - in '14 when they took over the Senate because at least businesses knew nothing disastrous like Dodd-Frank or Obamacare was going to come down the pike. But we've still got the NLRB out there and trying to inflict the joint employer standard on franchise businesses which would be a disaster. They're talking about ambush elections. We've got an administration that refuses to implement fixes to Obamacare like the 40-hour work week. We've got President Obama last year expanding, telling the Department of Labor to expand the class of employees that are entitled to overtime so people will be compensated for time spent rather than (INAUDIBLE) spent. And then you've got state and federal governments trying to come down with a minimum wage increases, what - at some point, and it really is about the $10, $12 point, you've got employees being paid more than they contribute to the profitability of the business.

CAVUTO: Then what do you do? I mean, in that - in that - in that environment, Andy, I mean, what do you do to get businesses feeling that Washington can have their back rather than stab them in the back because they have all this money - not necessarily small or medium-size businesses but the larger ones - have a lot of money abroad. $2 trillion that's just sitting offshore and it's not coming back because it's going to be double- taxed or taxed at a high rate so businesses keep it there including some very politically-correct names like Apple. How do you win that money back?

PUZDER: Well, there's really - really, the only way is to elect government - to elect politicians who are committed to seeing the economy grow, who are not committed to seeing the government grow. Most of these societal issues come down to an individual point of view and what's inside. If you can't trust your own self, of course you're not going to trust other people.

CAVUTO: You know, when you perform, song writer, entertainer -- it's always very uplifting, I'm told. I know that your whole approach is very positive, positive energy, and it's contagious.

I always tell young people, younger than you, I don't thinker than -- younger than my own kids that the bottom line is you are the vibe you let off.

And if you're negative, all that's going to be contagious. If you're positive, that too will be contagious. I think it starts there, but I could be simplistic. What do you think?

ANDREW W.K.: No, I agree with that. It's a code of ethics really that starts in your own behavior. It can seem rather trivial to imagine that how you interact with people throughout your day could actually have a global impact or at least even in your own community, but it really does.

If you don't have these strengths, if I don't have the strength to be polite to that stranger or have that trust, that kind of faith that humanity isn't bad, then how would I believe that the rest of the world --

CAVUTO: You can't blame a lot of people young or old, right, Andrew? I tried to give the benefit of the doubt to the government, let me down, markets, let me down, housing let me down. Again, and again, my trust was broken like a bad relationship, no more.

ANDREW W.K.: Well, a bad relationship is a very good example because if we're going on dates with someone and we have bad experiences, it's easy to want to cast aside all of romance, all of love, all relationships because you don't want to get hurt.

But we also don't want to live in a world where we don't have love or relationships or hold out hope for something more. Idealism is challenging. It's much easier to become cynical, but we don't want to live in that kind of world.

CAVUTO: Speak for yourself, young man. Andrew W.K., it is attitudinal, we are bigger than the problems that seem to confront us. I hope that helps everybody, and I want you to return next week bright-eyed, bushy-tailed and feeling we can conquer the world.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5FYK-G891-DXH2-654X-00000-00Trusting Real Estate; Down Payment Debate; Do You Trust Technology?; School System Skepticism; America's Trust Deficit; Businesses Leery of Government; Overcoming Market Fears; Media Trust Issues2015-05-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:41ZLexisNexisCAVUTO6:00 PM ESTSteve Moore, Basil Smikle, Andy Puzder, Brent Bozell, Lauren Ashburn, Tim Rood; Katrina Campins; Kurt Knutsson, David Kennedy, Ashley Pratte, Carole Hankin, Andrew W.K.NEWSBusiness050801cb.223Trusting Real Estate; Down Payment Debate; Do You Trust Technology?; School System Skepticism; America's Trust Deficit; Businesses Leery of Government; Overcoming Market Fears; Media Trust IssuesNeil Cavuto, Elizabeth MacDonald, Charles Payne

(OPENING MUSIC - "CAVUTO")

NEIL CAVUTO, HOST: Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto.

And America, we have a problem - a trust problem.

Right now, across the nation, we're seeing a loss of faith in all our institutions among all political types.

Investors burned by the financial crash staying out of the stock market. Home buyers singed by the real estate meltdown staying out of the housing market. A generation of kids exposed to both showing little interest in either. Their trust in institutions down. Their faith in marriage itself at an all-time low. Parents who've lost confidence at a public school system that fails their kids despite the government pouring billions of dollars into a system that fails to raise their test scores.

Now, it would be one thing if the media pounced on government's clear failures but more inclined to stay in government's hip pocket, convinced that the government isn't the problem, how much we are giving it is.

So a collective media call to doubledown on the spending that has yet to work. A weird trust in repeating the same mistakes only this time, with pricier mistakes and desperately hoping for a different result.

So you needn't be Einstein to figure that I'm right or left. This is just stupid - just an average American taxpayer whose gut says this has got to stop.

So tonight, we stop and we step back - way back. We're going to get to the bottom of why America keeps coming up short and it keeps coming back to trust.

So we've decided to give this issue (INAUDIBLE) the whole show because this isn't about the spending deficit or real estate deficit or a market deficit or faith deficit. This, my friends, is about America's trust deficit.

We begin with Washington's deficit.

Taxpayers are seeing lots of their tax money spent but what are they getting for all that spending? Now, more than half of Americans think that more government means more problems.

Steve Moore says taxpayers are tired of Washington spending (INAUDIBLE) after bad. Lizzie MacDonald says that at least the coverage of that isn't getting the proper coverage. And Basil Smikle says right now, this taxpayer trust is something that both parties need to address.

All right. So, Steve, first to you. How bad is this?

STEVE MOORE, HERITAGE FOUNDATION VISITING FELLOW: Well, it's really bad. I mean, I was thinking, Neil, when you asked me to do this show about how much Washington has changed in just the last 25 or 30 years I've been here. When I came to Washington, the federal government was spending about a trillion dollars. Now, Neil, it's going to - next year, it'll be spending $4 trillion. And even adjusted for inflation, that's more than doubling up the cost of government. And then you ask people, "Do you think government is better today than it was 30 or 40 years ago?" And people say, "I don't know." One other example, if I may, Neil, you mentioned schools. If you look at what's happened to per capita spending per pupil spending in the schools versus - let's say - the 1950s or 60s when schools were a lot better, we're spending about three times as much as we used to. So I think people are saying, "Wait a minute." Throwing more money at these problems as a lot of liberals (INAUDIBLE) after what happened in Baltimore if we just spent more money, people are saying, "You're crazy. That's the source of the problem. It's not going to solve the crisis."

CAVUTO: What do you think, Liz?

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: Well, I think Steve is exactly right and as for one, the media doesn't really cover it correctly. John (INAUDIBLE), the economist put out a great story and here's the thing, Neil. When the government spends money, that is added to GDP. So when the government doesn't spend money, politicians are afraid, "Oh, GDP is going to go down." So you could see the vicious circle that's in there. Also, we do have severe crony capitalism, of course. Watch this. Inspector General who oversees Medicare said, "Hey, wait a second." Medicare is not even negotiating drug rebates with drug manufacturers while Medicaid is. And so why? Because their laws written there says, "You know what? You're not allowed to - you can't interfere with the negotiation between drug companies and the federal government." What is that about? I'm not sure.

CAVUTO: What's even more alarming to me is when you talk to kids of all political stripes, party-affiliation, it's (INAUDIBLE) maybe it's just their blaming it on the parents or blaming it on the prior generations. They have an inherent distrust of Washington, an inherent distrust of institutions, an inherent distrust of any one of authority to get anything done.

BASIL SMIKLE, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: They do and that's unfortunate. Look, I am a person that doesn't necessarily believe that government is the answer to all of our problems but there is a sort of minimum that I think government sets where the (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Well, have we gone beyond the minimum?

SMIKLE: I don't think we've gone beyond the minimum but I think we've - there may be sort of a dearth of ideas. I think we need some better ideas, some (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: But to Lizzie's point, do you think the dearth of ideas is that we just go back to the same old idea? (INAUDIBLE).

SMIKLE: Listen, Neil, (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Let him finish.

SMIKLE: I go back to - I go back to a point when David Dinkins was mayor of New York City and asked the state to increase taxes to put more cops on the street. It was during his administration that you started to see a decline in crime here in New York City and a lot of it is pegged to an increase in taxation. So when I think when (INAUDIBLE) legislators (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Weird that you would mention David Dinkins, although with the present mayor, now Dinkins looks like Winston Churchill.

SMIKLE: Listen, it started - it started during his administration. Giuliani takes credit for it but that's OK. But.

CAVUTO: All right. Well, that's (INAUDIBLE).

SMIKLE: --the thing is if you point - if you point directly to the expenditure and the outcome then I think you will think (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Well, but Steve, my big fear with this is that we're going to go back to the same well and say, "Well, more money" or maybe we get a better idea how to spend that money better, but it's always going to be more, more, more. That's what worries me.

MOORE: Yes. I think the problem with this analysis that "Gee, if we only had more government", I think that the problem is this, Neil, that the government has gotten away from the core functions that it is supposed to do. It's supposed to educate our kids. It's supposed to build good roads and highways. It's supposed to defend us. It's not to allow things like what happened in Benghazi. And I would simply respond to this point that the government's not doing much. I think the reason the government is failing in the fundamental things it's supposed to be doing is because it's doing too much. I mean, a good example of this with young people because these polls show that young people are the ones who have lost the most confidence in government. And when I talk to my kids who are completely non-ideological - they don't listen to any of this political stuff. But you know what they don't get? They don't get how the federal government can't run a website for the healthcare system. They're like, "Wait a minute. A seventh-grader can do that."

MACDONALD: Yes. But we're (INAUDIBLE). But the thing is - here's the thing. Why raise taxes when the government is wasting so much money? More than a trillion dollars.

MOORE: Right, exactly.

MACDONALD: --worth of vacant federal office buildings littering the landscape. $200 billion in overlap and duplication in the federal government. And you have an incompetent health reform website that is just sucking up money right and left, that is really not working and it's all loaded on Medicaid whose budget is getting blown out right there.

SMIKLE: Yes, we're talking about - I mean, we don't need to be talking about a website here. What I think we need to be talking about are how government can help - help - solve problems but not be the conclusion. And even the president has said that.

CAVUTO: But think about (INAUDIBLE) - but why do you think that right after Baltimore, the immediate inclination was "We need more money", "We need more money", "We need more money." Baltimore in a per capita on a per student basis gets almost as much money as New York City students do. Number two to them. Neither are exactly breaking the mental walls down. So why is there a feeling that if in doubt, throw more money at it?

SMIKLE: Well, it's not the fact that you're throwing more money at it. It's how that money gets spent. And if you're - if you're - but if you're questioning (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: But they're not even fine-tuning it. They're saying it (INAUDIBLE) a matter they haven't (INAUDIBLE) enough money.

SMIKLE: I think it's important to be able to track where that money goes and make sure the outcomes.

CAVUTO: But they don't. They don't.

SMIKLE: --make sure the outcomes (INAUDIBLE). No, I think that's happening. That happened here in New York. It's happening in many other cities where you can actually see that additional.

CAVUTO: We spent trillions on a war on poverty and all that has yet to move the poverty needle.

SMIKLE: I think it's moved the needle quite significantly. But what.

CAVUTO: Three percent. Three percent.

SMIKLE: --but that's significant. What I do think is problematic though.

MACDONALD: It is?

CAVUTO: (INAUDIBLE) trillion dollars?

SMIKLE: If you talk to the people who came who.

MACDONALD: Three percent since the 60s? (INAUDIBLE).

SMIKLE: --(INAUDIBLE) - if you - if you talk about the people who came out of poverty, that's significant for them.

MACDONALD: Listen, we all - right. But we all want to help the poor. You know what helps the poor is a job, because then they become emotionally and literally invested in their area. They don't want to destroy their job or destroy the area around them.

CAVUTO: Well, do you think that's it? The trust - we don't trust the government to know that? Whether you like it or not, we don't trust them to do the right thing.

MACDONALD: We know we don't trust them because we've thrown so much money out already and it hasn't really worked.

SMIKLE: But I don't think - I also don't think that they're - I also don't think that anyone - whether either Democratic side or the Republican side, you all speak for that - but I certainly don't think any Democrat is saying, "Just throw money at the problem." That is not the solution. (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Actually, last week, they were. But by the way, (INAUDIBLE). You're right to say that both parties have failed in this regard because they do think even Republicans with defense, "Throw more money out. Throw more money out." But, Steve, what do you think of that - where we stand with the trust issue because when it comes to government, we don't stand too well here.

MOORE: Well, we don't. And I'll just give you one example of what you guys were talking about. I just had a piece in the "Wall Street Journal" this week about how we've got a D.C. voucher program that is educating kids in inner cities by allowing them to go in other schools. And here's the amazing thing about that program. It is educating kids, Neil, giving them a quality education for one-half of what it costs in the public schools and we can't get the liberals to support the program and it's helping a lot of kids.

CAVUTO: Well, there are lot of - there are a lot of players not measuring up here.

But, guys, I want to thank you all. (INAUDIBLE). You do this very, very well.

In the meantime, fastfood giant Andy Puzder says businesses shouldn't trust Washington either and either Republicans offering them help or Democrats because tax bills, red tape just seem to pile up and Uncle Sam just keeps piling on.

So Andy, how do you get businesses to believe that Washington has their back. 'Cause you've argued for many years now, they have a sense that it does not.

ANDY PUZDER, HARDEE'S & CARL'S JR CEO: Well, it did help in 2010 when the Republicans took over the House and then again in '12 when they - in '14 when they took over the Senate because at least businesses knew nothing disastrous like Dodd-Frank or Obamacare was going to come down the pike. But we've still got the NLRB out there and trying to inflict the joint employer standard on franchise businesses which would be a disaster. They're talking about ambush elections. We've got an administration that refuses to implement fixes to Obamacare like the 40-hour work week. We've got President Obama last year expanding, telling the Department of Labor to expand the class of employees that are entitled to overtime so people will be compensated for time spent rather than (INAUDIBLE) spent. And then you've got state and federal governments trying to come down with a minimum wage increases, what - at some point, and it really is about the $10, $12 point, you've got employees being paid more than they contribute to the profitability of the business.

CAVUTO: Then what do you do? I mean, in that - in that - in that environment, Andy, I mean, what do you do to get businesses feeling that Washington can have their back rather than stab them in the back because they have all this money - not necessarily small or medium-size businesses but the larger ones - have a lot of money abroad. $2 trillion that's just sitting offshore and it's not coming back because it's going to be double- taxed or taxed at a high rate so businesses keep it there including some very politically-correct names like Apple. How do you win that money back?

PUZDER: Well, there's really - really, the only way is to elect government - to elect politicians who are committed to seeing the economy grow, who are not committed to seeing the government grow. We've elected a president - now, he's been president six years - President Obama who's committed to big government. And if you're committed to big government, you're going to scare businesses. Until you get that commitment to economic growth, to getting people jobs, to creating opportunity and reducing poverty by creating jobs, by creating economic growth, until the government gets that kind of focus, the businesses aren't going to trust the government. You're always looking forward to additional and added expenses and the higher your expenses are, the lower your profits are. The lower your projected profits, the less like you are to expand, the less like you are to build a new business, are to open a new business, and the less like you are to create jobs. So until this big government attitude begins to decline. Look, we spent last year, the National Association of Manufacturers and the Small Business Administration estimated that we're spending about $2 trillion. American businesses are spending $2 trillion in compliance costs with the current - in the current regulatory environment. Now, my buddy, Steve More was just mentioning that the government spends $4 trillion. Well, half of that amount - you could take half of that amount and you'd increase the amount that businesses are on tap for by $2 trillion which is what they have to pay in regulatory compliance costs. I mean, it's a very bad situation.

CAVUTO: Imagine. That's the equivalent of the money they have - they have offshore. It is a very interesting fact.

Andy, always good seeing you.

PUZDER: Well, nobody's going to bring the money back unless you get (INAUDIBLE) if you're going to have to pay more taxes on it. And the bad thing is when foreign companies bring that money back, they don't have to pay tax on it. So.

CAVUTO: Now, I love you to death, Andy, but I don't trust you in this sense that you are a fastfood executive and you're thin. So that doesn't jive with me. I've told you this many, many times. So it takes away all your credibility.

But I kid you. But, Andy, as always, a pleasure. And I love the piece you wrote about Scott Walker keeping in mind the numbers are not what the mainstream media says, it's just how they play with those numbers.

But, Andy, always good seeing you.

PUZDER: Thank you. I appreciate it.

CAVUTO: Thank you very, very much. Andy Puzder.

Well, we've heard of "The Young and the Restless", right? But young and investless? Because when it comes to stocks, most young folks want nothing to do with them.

Next, why Charles Payne says trust him, you'll regret sitting this one out, guys.

CAVUTO: Well, here's why they often call this market a stealth rally. So many aren't even participating in it. In fact, more than half of Americans don't own any stock at all after this incredible run-up because they don't trust this run-up. They don't trust stocks. When things go south, investors run scared.

Just look at what happened on October 19, 1987. I was there for the scare.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO (VOICEOVER): Suddenly, it was a freefall. A better than 22 percent (INAUDIBLE) in the Dow and nervous traders were looking over their shoulders.

CAVUTO: What they don't know and in fact readily worry about is how far down that correction really has to go, how long it will take, and exactly how many more people will be hurt in the process before the market does decide - if it decides - to turn around.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Well, you'll be happy to know that markets did come back and puberty did kick in. And now you know the rest of the story.

I hate when my staff does this to remind me, same Lego hair then, same Lego hair now.

Anyway, after the 2008 meltdown, just when people thought stocks couldn't get any lower, they did bounce back to record highs.

Charles Payne says now, lots of investors are kicking themselves for missing both opportunities.

But it happens a lot. You can understand in the moment, they're frantic.

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: Oh, sure. Sure.

CAVUTO: But here's where I think it's different with this one, Charles, is that once, twice burned, whatever, a lot of young people in particular, "I don't want anything to do with it."

PAYNE: Yes. There's no doubt about it. And there's a lot of young people who have sort of watched it from afar as they were growing up. And you see your parents like, "Golly, we lost it all." And a few years later, "Golly, we lost it all." And so - then of course, say, "Well, you know what? We're real estate investors now. Golly, we lost it all." So now you hear that they'd rather just have experiences that the - that the big F.O.M.O. - the fear of missing out - isn't on making a lot of money but missing the fun things in life. So you put it all off - family formation, investing - all that stuff, put it off because you might as well live in the moment, have fun while you're young because you don't know what's right around the corner.

CAVUTO: Is it their parents' experiences singed them or what?

PAYNE: I think it has. But I also think - what I find really interesting is that we're starting now to see this group come out of it, not come out of it but starting to emerge as entrepreneurs, family formation. They're still renters above buyers and I think you're going to start seeing them invest in things because they're in the midst of all the excitement that the WhatsApps, the Periscopes, all these things that seem to pop up overnight, they're the ones that are making it happen.

CAVUTO: And they're gravitating those (INAUDIBLE) for jobs because they think they're still interested in getting money, it's just they don't want to get at the means in the market or whatever.

PAYNE: They love spending it. Right? I mean, just like YOLO - "You Only Live Once", right, so yes, it's good. They love spending it, particularly their parents. But the sooner - at some point, "like I scratched the room", yes.

CAVUTO: All right. So but you say to what - to kids in general, young people in general, millennials, let's say for want of a better definition, the 18-29, 30-year-olds who are saying, "I don't trust that (INAUDIBLE)."

PAYNE: They've got all their - they've got too much money in cash. Cash goes nowhere - deteriorates every single day in worth and what it can buy. And I think they're going to (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: But when the George Soros's, the Druckermillers - all these guys start talking about, "Hey, this is getting a little long in the tooth", do you blame them?

PAYNE: It is a little long in the tooth that - but I mean, I don't know that they should try to play the market timing thing because you (INAUDIBLE) - you'd started this whole thing off the right way. When we are in the midst of a crash, everyone's running. Very few people have the wherewithal to buy. If you can't buy now, you really think you're going to buy in the middle of a crash? But if you're 23.

CAVUTO: Well, what do you tell them, Charles?

PAYNE: --well, if you're 25-years-old, if you're lucky, you'll probably go through another 10 crashes. I personally hope I live through at least another five major crashes. That means I'll be 90-years-old. And - but at the end of the day, when the smoke clears, usually what happens over the last 20 years, the markets at a new all-time high. What they have to do is don't trust Wall Street, trust the things you like. You love Under Armour clothes, own Under Armour. Go with what you do trust. You're right. There's a lot of shenanigans on Wall Street, there's a lot of knuckleheads and there's a lot of thievery. I'd be the first to admit that. But only a great company over a long period of time, normally you should do pretty well.

CAVUTO: But a lot of people feel young, they don't market (INAUDIBLE) we're close to what - the fifth anniversary of the flash.

PAYNE: Sure. Sure.

CAVUTO: A lot of people say, "See, that's what happens. Just when you get in, some idiot does it."

PAYNE: There's no doubt about it. Listen, high-frequency trading isn't illegal but it makes the market more volatile. And there's always - there's too much money. Govenrment and Wall Street. There will always be theft. There's just too much money sloshing around.

CAVUTO: So what do you tell people who said, let's say, they like Nike or they like Apple and they say, "Gee, Charles, I agree. Buy what you like. Like what you buy. Know what you're buying." But if the stocks (INAUDIBLE) already very rich."

PAYNE: It's just hard to say. They could be rich temporarily. In other words, sometimes the valuation can get ahead of the actual fundamentals. But they - the fundamentals are also improving.

CAVUTO: And they were saying that about Apple at $50, at $60 a share.

PAYNE: Trying to pick the top is a tough game.

CAVUTO: Do you just say, "Hold tight"?

PAYNE: Because you're not going to pick the bottom. You're not going to pick the bottom. So if you're going to be in it and that you're 25, start to nibble. You know it's great. You're making (INAUDIBLE) great. These young people know more than anybody on Wall Street. They know the greatest things going on right now. If they can just put their money with what they know, connect those two dots, they'll have an amazing life. They can have the fear of missing out for the rest of their lives and have a fun youth, a fun middle age, and an amazing golden age.

CAVUTO: I just find that they whine a lot. Just shut up, right?

All right. Thank you very, very much.

PAYNE: But that whining gets them what they want.

CAVUTO: Yes. "Get off my lawn!"

Meanwhile, a quick quiz. If Americans trust the government the least, who do you think is - well - next to least? The president, the media, big business, or Charles Payne?

No. The answer right after this.

CAVUTO: The government does this. The government can do that.

Is the media simply too busy kissing up to the government to objectively cover the government? Because the media itself is now one of the least trusted institutions, second only to Congress.

That's according to at least one recent poll.

Media watchers, Brent Bozell, Lauren Ashburn say that the fourth estate stopped being the government's watchdog decades ago.

Well, Brent, it's very interesting to me that despite all of that, it's like the media wants to doubledown on this faith in government and question those who would dare question government.

BRENT BOZELL, MEDIA RESEARCH CENTER PRESIDENT: Yes. Isn't it incredible that their response to be marginalized is to be even more marginalized. They've become so radicalized. We've seen something in the last two years that I frankly hadn't seen before. This - since 2008, I should say, this commitment, this deliberate commitment not to report news if it harms the narrative of the left. This is not one example. This is not two examples. I can give you 20 examples. As a matter of fact, you and I have talked about this many times on your show. They are deliberately not reporting news.

CAVUTO: Lauren, to what end though? I mean, they must know that they hurt their own brand. We've seen it happen in print. We've seen it happen with one newspaper or another whether they hop online or not. The content is what people are getting turned off to.

LAUREN ASHBURN, THE HILL CONTRIBUTOR: I think that's true. I do need to respond to what Brent just said because I think.

CAVUTO: Let Lauren respond. Go ahead.

ASHBURN: --that he's - because I think he's wrong, coming up especially with Hillary Clinton, you had the New York Times breaking the email scandal. You had all of the mainstream news organizations hopping on this latest scandal with the Clinton Foundation. So.

CAVUTO: But I'm talking about government itself. We're talking about whether faith in government can fix problems.

ASHBURN: No, I understand.

CAVUTO: Go ahead.

ASHBURN: I understand. But I think that there are also a lot of journalists who do put their heads down and do the hard work. The FOIA requests are very important in order to find out exactly what is happening and you can't marginalized those. They are about this many reporters who are doing it. But I think that it's very important to know that if you get the right news source.

CAVUTO: But that's the problem. That - see, Lauren, that's the problem. If only this many are reporting it or whatever, this signifies small percentage - the others are saying especially after Baltimore last week, well, the issue is we're not spending enough. We're not - the government isn't doing enough, in other words, that the government can fix it. That's what worries me.

Brent?

BOZELL: Look, with all due respect. Lauren, what you just said is just pure nonsense. They have not gotten to the bottom of a single one of the Obama scandals. They did not get to the bottom of a single one of the Clinton scandals. Just think about their coverage of Watergate and Nixon where they would not let go 'til they got to the bottom of it. Now, look at the IRS. Look at Benghazi. Look at the VA. Look at so many scandals they've been dropped. This one - this Clinton one - will be dropped as well.

CAVUTO: But let's go back to the government, guys. I can argue how zealous the media is when reporting on the Clinton issues, whatever, but I think back to this idea that if we have problems, the government can fix them. Lauren, do you think that is a media issue to address, that they're not really looking at anything more creative than that?

ASHBURN: Well, I mean, I think that's a very left - right - way of looking at the world. If there are problems then the government can fix them. I think that if you're looking at news coverage of that specific issue, you're not going to find it because I think a lot of the people who do report think that exactly that - that the government can fix issues. However, you did have the reporting on the VA scandal, right, where there was complete mismanagement and you did see the media latch onto that and paint the VA as villains. I'm not here to defend all of the terrible journalism that's going on right now and there is a lot of it because it's certainly a lot easier right now to pontificate and to spout off than it is to actually take a big 30,000 foot view and take a look at what the government is actually doing with our dollars.

CAVUTO: Well, Brent, though, only (INAUDIBLE) and I've raised this with Republicans too who find that a $600 billion defense budget isn't cutting it. If you're digging a hole, it's best to put the spending shovel down or the big government shovel down. What do you think?

BOZELL: Well, here's - I think - a real direct answer to your question. If you look at a problem - a perceived problem - you will never hear on the networks the idea (INAUDIBLE) "Leave it alone. Leave people alone. Let people (INAUDIBLE). Let people show some personal responsibility. Get government out of the equation." You'll never hear that. Instead, you'll hear a discussion about how much the government needs to do.

CAVUTO: All right, guys. I wish we had more time 'cause I don't - I wish you guys could have actually come to blows but you're two locations. It makes it very, very hard to do. But next time. Next time.

Guys, thank you both very much. Well, burn if you're in, burn more if you're out. Next, the housing pro says keeping the housing faith will pay off big time, but you got to give it time.

It's one thing to not trust the education system, but quite another to rebel against it. Coming up, how parents are revolting with an education system they think's revolting.

CAVUTO: I get the idea that trusting big institution is fleeting. In this hour, we're digging into exactly why? A big reason, of course, goes back to the 2007 housing bubble. Once the housing market crashed, however, confidence in real estate itself crashed along with it.

And now home ownership is at a better than quarter century low, as Americans are pulling a 180 on this big American dream.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I don't have the money to buy a house.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Move too much. Too much money, I'm never going to have that much.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I can't afford to buy.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I don't think I'm mature enough yet for it.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: If you buy a house, you have to stay there.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Why buy a house if you are going to sail on it and ruin your credit ratings.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Renting is easier. Things have taken care of for you.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: And probably because we are too poor. We have no money.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CAVUTO: As you can see, a lot of millennials are simply opting to rent rather than buy, but former Fannie Mae executive, Tim Rood, says that is a big mistake. They are missing on a moment to make a good investment and make a good return.

But if you think about it, a lot of these kids are saying, I haven't seen that return. My parents haven't seen that return, what do you say?

TIM ROOD, FORMER FANNIE MAE EXECUTIVE: Thanks, Neil. So you just saw or made the reference to the housing home ownership rates dropping to 63 percent. When you think about these numbers in the aggregate or the abstract, they don't mean a lot.

But there is a lot of financial implications when you think about every 1 percent of that drop is actually one million households that aren't owning a home. That's one million households paying 30 percent more a month for their living expenses. There are one million households --

CAVUTO: They figure they are saving on the hassle and the risk of another meltdown. That's what they say, you say what?

ROOD: Absolutely. Look, there's always going to be some casualties in the housing. If you can get 95 percent success rate, which means 5 percent are going to lose home to foreclosure. Obviously, it's a cautionary tale.

That's 95 percent of folks who see the wealth appreciation of home ownership which it's important to remember, the household net worth of a renter is $5,000 in this country.

The household net worth of a home owner is $150,000. But Neil, the big picture was accidentally exposed recently on boomers. They showed seniors when they passed away, how much financial net worth was in their house, and it turns out only 20 percent of these seniors when they passed away had any financial net worth beyond the home equity in their house.

So you can imagine during the most prosperous time, that's the end result. We've got to focus on how to get more folks into housing today.

CAVUTO: All right, but there are a lot of people in the last seven, eight- year period since the meltdown who would not have that appreciation at all so they would not have the housing component of that wealth, right?

ROOD: Well, I think people talk like that, but in real terms, you've seen about $3 trillion of appreciation in housing over the last three years. It bottomed out in 2012, but it is rallying and we are still about 15 percent from the highs.

CAVUTO: So you say give it time and have faith that in time things come back?

ROOD: Well, there's a huge demand push. Americans are funny. At no point in history have been more Americans that have a desire to live indoors. I mean, we keep growing the population and ultimately 65 percent historically are going to want to buy a house.

You've seen people who have lost their house to foreclosure. There is 6 million, 9 million of these people, who have lost their house to foreclosure. That when polled they still say that --

CAVUTO: And they want back in.

ROOD: They want back in. It's a good investment.

CAVUTO: Thank you, Tim, very, very much. Good to seeing you.

Well, to people that have a right to not trust the housing market or to Tim's point, they going way too far and being way too jaded? Banks are trying to tempt them in, but are they really doing too much here offering as little as 3 percent down mortgages.

Well, real estate analyst, Katrina Campins, said this is the kind of thing that worries here that some of the banks and institutions are sucking them back in, to be slaughtered.

KATRINA CAMPINS, FORMER "APPRENTICE" CONTESTANT: Right, and I believe that the concern is twofold. First, I think a lot of these borrowers are not aware that they run the risk of their house actually being worth less than they owe if the market for some reason declines, which historically it may.

And with these small down payments, borrowers are also not aware they'll get a higher interest rate and the cost of the loan in the long run will be higher than if they put more of a down payment down, not to mention mortgage insurance.

I think also the lenders run a risk of these borrowers walking away because they don't have enough skin in the game. So I think it's extremely dangerous and you know, God knows that I love people buying real estate. That's what I do for a living.

However, I'm also concerned that maybe these banks are giving people too much without enough skin in the game. And without educating them that through the life of the loan, it may seem like an opportunity to appreciate and to buy into the American dream without enough money down, but in the long run, I think that it's a mistake.

CAVUTO: You know, Katrina, the argument for letting these low money down loans go through is most young people since it's targeted largely at young people, do have the financial discipline to stick with the mortgage, grow with the mortgage as they grow with their jobs.

If you don't do something like this, it will only be a rich man/rich woman's market and we'll never see housing stabilize. What do you make of that argument?

CAMPINS: Well, I think it comes down to employment as well. You know, the unemployment rate with the younger generation just isn't rising at the rate that we need it in order for them to build this wealth.

I think one other point which is not realized is that now the banks are actually allowing these younger generation to get down payment from family members, which again, if you don't earn it, I'm a firm believer, if you earn it, you value it more.

A family member is actually putting that down payment for you then you're more inclined to walk away than if you worked hard for it. I think part of the American dream is working really hard to be able to attain it.

So I'm a firm believer that again, you have to work for it, and in the end, the housing market will do better because of it.

CAVUTO: All right, unless you have a rich uncle who doesn't seem to care. Katrina, thank you very, very much. Good seeing you again.

CAMPINS: Thank you.

CAVUTO: Well, from the reaction we got on the street, the things you don't trust the most are the things you apparently use the most?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm on Facebook. I'm on Twitter. All our information is out there, anyway.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: If you try to get rid of your page, it's like always there.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: They definitely have the technology to see everything everybody does.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I'm getting pop-ups, advertisements and things I've searched in the past.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Every day I think why am I still doing this?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Trust in technology is fading, but are we the problem it is still a big thing? Well, Americans don't want their data in the hands of big tech companies or the government for that matter or both. They're more addicted to it than ever before.

To cybersecurity experts, David Kennedy and Kurt Knutsson, who says this technology that we may not like, we apparently still love. It is weird, right? It's like a double-edged sword.

KURT KNUTSSON, "KURT THE CYBER GUY": Most people don't know when they're using Cloud storage, when your information is stored on various servers, they think it's up in an atmosphere, but no, it's giant farms of servers in various parts of the world.

CAVUTO: And they don't care or they don't know the details like making hot dogs.

KNUTSSON: Here's when you care, the moment you care is when you took something that is really important to you and you're working on it, like a book you are writing, and you store it on a service that isn't your own computer or device, and all of a sudden one day, poof! It's gone.

What the heck happened? This thing that's shared on all of your devices available anywhere and you have to revert to a copy stored six months ago.

CAVUTO: And then it becomes a nightmare. You know, David, I've always remembered the former Sun Microsystems CEO Scott McNealy said if you want your privacy, it is gone, the technology and convenience obviously has some intrusions on privacy. But its benefits outweigh whatever annoyances you encounter. Do you agree with that?

DAVID KENNEDY, TRUSTEDSEC FOUNDER: Well, I still think there is a fine balance between privacy and the types of information you put online, but the problem is that. I mean, you are integrating technology into everything that you do on a regular basis.

I mean, with your Android phones, iPhones, with Macs, all of those have call backs and stored data on these Cloud infrastructures that store this type of information.

So to put it short, our privacy is pretty much gone when it comes to the amount of information that we do on these pieces of technology, but we still have to be cautious about the types of information we put up there.

KNUTSSON: David, I would jump in and say cautious is the easy word. You have to be stupid to store something critical in your life. Do not put a will, medical records, personal data, nothing that would --

CAVUTO: But medical data, that is getting online.

KNUTSSON: Well, you may not have a choice. You are not the one who is control of that so perhaps --

CAVUTO: So let's say you are doing everything right, but someone else is deciding to take that data.

KNUTSSON: One little leak in the faucet from one point to the next point is what goes wrong.

CAVUTO: I got a guy like you, when is the last time you wrote a paper check, you do everything probably online?

KNUTSSON: I mean, you and I probably -- because I lose them.

CAVUTO: You have people who do that.

KNUTSSON: It's not about that. When I do it, I lose.

CAVUTO: What is a smart move? The convenience of it this is such and you can do it so quickly dictates this new world. Even though we know in our back of our minds, there is a risk of something going wrong, we like the convenience.

KENNEDY: Listen, we want to be able to have as much convenience as possible. We want to be able to order our groceries and then go pick them up at the store. You have toilets you can control from the smartphones now. Convenience is huge.

The problem is it's not just consumers that are doing this as well. It's businesses and that's completely out of our control. Businesses are putting medical data, Social Security number, sensitive data, financial records in these Cloud infrastructures, which are not protected.

So it's a much wider issue than just the consumer themselves. It's wider on the business front as well, and that's why you are seeing a lot of these breaches occur. It's going to be a problem to come and something we face directly in the next two years.

CAVUTO: We love technology, but don't think it is going to be there for us.

KENNEDY: I like my smart toilet.

CAVUTO: Who doesn't? But it's a family show. Look at the time. I want you to look at this chart. With education spending like, this you would think test scores would be off the charts. News flash, they're not. No wonder where a lot of parents are flat-out serious over all this flat lining.

CAVUTO: All right, to all these skeptical parents and kids about our schools, 31 percent of just parents do not trust the government's handling of all of this.

Students aren't getting results, even as taxpayer dollars are being thrown again, billion after billion after billion into school systems.

To Ashley Pratte and a former New York school superintendent, Carole Hankin, on if there is a way to fix, what many think, is now a broken educational system. Ashley, what do you think?

ASHLEY PRATTE, FP1 STRATEGIES VP OF COMMUNICATIONS: I think that the whole idea of throwing money at a problem as a solution is not a solution, and I think that's the real issue here. We look at accountability of schools and test scores and everything and they're just plummeting and failing our students.

And parents and students deserve options and they deserve choice. That's why I think the school choice movement is so important. Students shouldn't be relegated to a school based on zip code. Students learn in different environments.

I think that, you know, an age where technology is rampant and we have choice at our fingertips, it should be the same way for education, and students should have that option as well as parents to say if my student is not thriving in this environment and I know that they can thrive elsewhere, that's where they are going to go school.

CAVUTO: I think what she's saying, Carole, is she's pro-choice on education.

PRATTE: That's a good way of putting it on that issue.

DR. CAROLE HANKIN, FORMER NEW YORK SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENT: I don't think pro-choice is the problem or the solution. I think that we have so many schools in this country, and just saying that students can go to other schools won't work every place. I do believe --

CAVUTO: Works in a lot of places, Carole.

HANKIN: Well, small amounts of students and what happen to the ones who can't get out? I think we need to fix the schools, but I absolutely agree that throwing more money is not the answer.

CAVUTO: Well, wouldn't competition would help?

HANKIN: I think competition helps in every single field, yes, but I also think that we need to do something with the schools that are broken.

CAVUTO: What do you make of that, Ashley? That if it's a matter of just the same existing system, challenging that that existing system with a competitors, does put a little bit of kick in your step.

PRATTE: Yes, and I'm all for competition, I think that's what's important with the rise of teachers unions, and I'm not bashing teachers here. My sister is one, and it's noble work she's doing.

This is why I wonder where the money is going, Neil? Because she has to take money out of her pocket to buy supplies for students in her classroom so you know, with all the money funnelled in, and you look at schools in Baltimore because that's been in the news recently. You see $15,000 per student.

Where is all of that money going? Is it going to the betterment of the students? When teachers have to take money out of their own pocketbooks or checkbooks to pay for supplies for their students that makes me wonder where exactly is the money being funnelled to?

Is it helping the students? I don't think so and it's definitely not helping the teachers.

CAVUTO: OK, I want to thank you guys very much. By now you get it, America has big trust issues, but next, rocker, Andrew W.K., one of the more optimistic guys I know here to build trust facts for the middle-aged, the young, the old, you name it. That's next.

CAVUTO: You know, this hour we have laid out eight out of ten millennials don't even trust other people even other young people. To the guy a lot of you who call the philosopher of partying because he just takes all the tension and brings it down a notch. Rocker, Andrew W.K., on if Americans can ever start trusting each other again.

Andrew, it's always good to have you, but I think that's the heart of the problem here, forget institutions, it's inherent thing, we don't trust or actually flip over each other. What's the problem?

ANDREW W.K., "PHILOSOPHER OF PARTYING": Well, this is a puzzling and perplexing issue but, fortunately, it is as simple as trusting one's self. Most of these societal issues come down to an individual point of view and what's inside. If you can't trust your own self, of course you're not going to trust other people.

CAVUTO: You know, when you perform, song writer, entertainer -- it's always very uplifting, I'm told. I know that your whole approach is very positive, positive energy, and it's contagious.

I always tell young people, younger than you, I don't thinker than -- younger than my own kids that the bottom line is you are the vibe you let off.

And if you're negative, all that's going to be contagious. If you're positive, that too will be contagious. I think it starts there, but I could be simplistic. What do you think?

ANDREW W.K.: No, I agree with that. It's a code of ethics really that starts in your own behavior. It can seem rather trivial to imagine that how you interact with people throughout your day could actually have a global impact or at least even in your own community, but it really does.

If you don't have these strengths, if I don't have the strength to be polite to that stranger or have that trust, that kind of faith that humanity isn't bad, then how would I believe that the rest of the world --

CAVUTO: You can't blame a lot of people young or old, right, Andrew? I tried to give the benefit of the doubt to the government, let me down, markets, let me down, housing let me down. Again, and again, my trust was broken like a bad relationship, no more.

ANDREW W.K.: Well, a bad relationship is a very good example because if we're going on dates with someone and we have bad experiences, it's easy to want to cast aside all of romance, all of love, all relationships because you don't want to get hurt.

But we also don't want to live in a world where we don't have love or relationships or hold out hope for something more. Idealism is challenging. It's much easier to become cynical, but we don't want to live in that kind of world.

CAVUTO: Speak for yourself, young man. Andrew W.K., it is attitudinal, we are bigger than the problems that seem to confront us. I hope that helps everybody, and I want you to return next week bright-eyed, bushy-tailed and feeling we can conquer the world.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XKC-CWY1-F03R-N06K-00000-00Trust issues loom large over Google's ambitious healthcare plans2019-11-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:41ZLexisNexisTrust issues loom large over Google's ambitious healthcare plansRavie Lakshmanan

Nov 21, 2019( TheNextWeb.com: http://thenextweb.com Delivered by Newstex) Google's healthcare deal with Ascension has rightly attracted a lot of scrutiny, and now the search giant has stepped in once again to clarify the controversial undertaking. David Feinberg, the head of Google's health initiatives, said[1] the company is working towards building an 'intelligent suite of tools to help doctors, nurses, and other providers take better care of patients, leveraging our expertise in organizing information.' Last week, it emerged that Google had struck a partnership with the US' second largest health system Ascension[2]— called 'Project Nightingale' — to develop AI-based tools in exchange for moving all the patient data to its cloud infrastructure. The idea was to build a searchable, cloud-based platform to query patient data[3], which the company could then market to other healthcare providers.

Feinberg, who outlined this vision at the HLTH conference earlier this month, reiterated the company's plans for designing tools with an aim to make 'health records more useful, more accessible and more searchable by pulling them into a single, easy-to-use interface for doctors.' 'Ascension is the first partner where we are working with the frontline staff to pilot this tool,' Feinberg said[4]. Acknowledging the challenges involved in the effort, Google stated the agreement allows Ascension to share patient info under current healthcare privacy laws, provided said information is used only to help the entity meet its clinical functions. The search giant also emphasized that it's putting strict controls in place to ensure sensitive health care is handled properly: To configure, test, tune and maintain the service in a clinical setting, a limited number of screened and qualified Google staff may be exposed to real data. These staff undergo HIPAA and medical ethics training, and are individually and explicitly approved by Ascension for a limited time. This would also necessitate that adequate safeguards are in place to anonymize the information[5] before it could be used to develop machine learning models for personalized healthcare.Trading personal information for better healthcareFeinberg's response comes after the Congress raised concerns about the collaboration[6], calling it 'disturbing' in part because of Ascension's decision not to notify its patients before moving ahead with the partnership. As the big tech companies extend their reach to markets that transcend their original mission — Facebook is no longer just a social network[7], Google is no longer about search, and Amazon is not just a retail platform — they're increasingly battling trust issues[8], with people wondering what happens when a company that knows so much about them gets access to their financial and health data. Speaking to The Guardian[9], a purported whistleblower involved in the project[10] said: 'Most Americans would feel uncomfortable if they knew their data was being haphazardly transferred to Google without proper safeguards and security in place. This is a totally new way of doing things. Do you want your most personal information transferred to Google? I think a lot of people would say no.' It doesn't help that the company's own record with other healthcare projects[11] isn't exactly stellar.Yet, five out of six UK hospitals renewed their data sharing agreements[12] with the company back in September. Amnesty International, in a 60-page 'Surveillance Giants[13]' report published yesterday, came out strongly against Facebook and Google, criticizing that their surveillance-based business model is inherently incompatible with the right to privacy and threatens freedom of opinion and expression, while recommending tech companies to 'find ways to transition to a rights-respecting business model.' If anything, the development underscores the urgent need for developing data governance models[14] that ensure access to sensitive information is tightly regulated, transparent, and done the right way. Until then, the digital institutions will dowhatever it takes to advance their interests and profit from venturing into new territories — especially what with healthcare industry becoming a lucrative $3 trillion market in the US that's impossible to ignore. There's no doubting the transformative power technology in advancing healthcare, but in the wrong hands, it could easily result in major privacy violations, undermining consumer trust in the process. urn:contentItem:5XJS-RFM1-DYDW-73R6-00000-00Trust issues loom large over Google's ambitious healthcare plans2019-11-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:41ZLexisNexisTrust issues loom large over Google's ambitious healthcare plansNew Delhi, 2019-11-22 14:47:32

November 22 -- Google has stepped in once again to clarify its healthcare data-sharing deal with Ascension after the controversial undertaking attracted significant privacy blowback for collecting sensitive patient data from millions of Americans without their consent.
David Feinberg, the head of Google's health initiatives, defended the move, stating the company is working towards building an "intelligent suite of tools to help doctors, nurses, and other providers take better care of patients, leveraging our expertise in organizing information."


 Last week, it emerged that Google had struck a partnership with the US non-profit healthcare provider Ascension - called "Project Nightingale" - to develop AI-based tools in exchange for moving all the patient data to its cloud infrastructure.
At it core, the idea is to build a searchable, cloud-based platform to query patient data, which the company could then market to other healthcare providers.
Feinberg, who outlined this vision at the HLTH conference in Las Vegas earlier this month, reiterated its plans for designing tools with an aim to make "health records more useful, more accessible and more searchable by pulling them into a single, easy-to-use interface for doctors."
"Ascension is the first partner where we are working with the frontline staff to pilot this tool," Feinberg said.
Acknowledging the challenges involved in the effort, Google stated the agreement allows Ascension to share patient info under current healthcare privacy laws, provided said information is used only to help the entity meet its clinical functions.
 
 
 
The search giant also emphasized that it's putting strict controls in place to ensure sensitive health care is handled properly:
To configure, test, tune and maintain the service in a clinical setting, a limited number of screened and qualified Google staff may be exposed to real data. These staff undergo HIPAA and medical ethics training, and are individually and explicitly approved by Ascension for a limited time.
This endeavor to centralize patient information would also necessitate that adequate safeguards are in place to anonymize the information before it could be used to develop machine learning models for personalized healthcare.
Trading personal information for better healthcareFeinberg's response comes after the Congress raised concerns about the collaboration, calling it "disturbing" in part because of Ascension's decision not to notify its patients before moving ahead with the partnership.
As the big tech companies extend their reach to markets that transcend their original mission - Facebook is no longer just a social network, Google is no longer about search, and Amazon is not just a retail platform - they're increasingly battling trust issues, with people wondering what happens when a company that knows so much about them gets access to their financial and health data.
Speaking to The Guardian, a purported whistleblower involved in the project said: "Most Americans would feel uncomfortable if they knew their data was being haphazardly transferred to Google without proper safeguards and security in place. This is a totally new way of doing things. Do you want your most personal information transferred to Google? I think a lot of people would say no."
It doesn't help that the company's own record with other healthcare projects isn't exactly stellar. Yet, five out of six UK hospitals renewed their data sharing agreements with the Mountain View-based tech giant back in September.
 
 
 
Amnesty International, in a 60-page "Surveillance Giants" report published yesterday, came out strongly against Facebook and Google, criticizing that their surveillance-based business model is inherently incompatible with the right to privacy and threatens freedom of opinion and expression, while recommending tech companies to "find ways to transition to a rights-respecting business model."
If anything, the development underscores the urgent need for developing data governance models that ensure access to sensitive information is tightly regulated, transparent, and done the right way.
Until that happens, the powerful digital institutions will do whatever it takes to advance their interests and profit from venturing into new territories - especially what with the healthcare industry becoming a lucrative $3 trillion market in the US that's impossible to ignore.
There's no doubting the transformative power technology in advancing healthcare, but in the wrong hands, it could easily result in major privacy violations, undermining consumer trust in the process.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WDK-1571-JD34-V0FK-00000-00Trust Zuckerberg in money system? You're kidding;Tech observed2019-06-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:40ZLexisNexisCOMPUTERSPg. 19Trust Zuckerberg in money system? You're kiddingTech observedPaul Smith

When Facebook announced its plans for colonisation of the financial world last week, it broke from its tried and trusted public relations plan, and sought to engage with journalists ahead of time to shape the narrative.

Anyone who has covered matters related to Facebook over the years knows that, at best, a favoured journo may be tipped off to the impending publication of a Facebook post on a new initiative, written by its overlord Mark Zuckerberg.

But for the announcement of the Libra cryptocurrency and its accompanying not-for-profit Libra Association it went for a more traditional approach - targeting the best financial services and banking journalists in different countries, such as The Australian Financial Review's James Eyers, and giving them hefty documents to digest.

When Zuckerberg's post announcing its plan went live on Facebook last Tuesday night, it came 10 minutes after the first embargoed stories had hit websites around the world ... a minor detail you might think, but carefully planned to try to ensure he was not directly quoted, or a central figure in the initial stories. Facebook and Zuckerberg's reputation for truth and accountability are so far gone that the company is doing its best to drive this push for a financial services revolution without it looking too much like it is a Facebook thing.

The idea of a new global currency and blockchain-based payments network is fine, and Calibra/Libra has good potential in offering banking services to people in parts of the world where they have been lacking.

Kenya-founded M-Pesa has, of course, already been offering mobile phone based payments and banking services across 10 such countries since 2007, but anything that threatens to kill the banks' foreign exchange fee golden goose can't be 100 per cent bad.

However, the idea that should kill this all dead (or at least halt its immediate progress) is simply Facebook's involvement itself. Its leaders have to be dreaming if they think they deserve to be trusted with any involvement in people's finances.

Regulators around the world have already made it clear that this won't develop without significant scrutiny, and Facebook's lack of credibility should play a major part in any deliberations.

"We feel that over the long run, if we can earn people's trust and if we can build a successful network with a lot of consumers on it, we can start offering all sorts of other financial services such as lending," David Marcus, the head of the Calibra digital wallet product, said.

Well, that is a very big "if". Facebook is so far in arrears on trust that its words are worth less than the thousands of dead or dying cryptocurrencies already rotting in cyberspace.

Marcus' words showed Calibra is just the first step in the eyes of Facebook's leadership, to worm its way into the financial heart of users' lives.

Though he insisted that Facebook will not have access to financial data on Calibra for advertising purposes, and that Zuckerberg was insistent on it being owned and controlled "as a public good", why on earth should anyone believe them?

Despite Facebook being just one of 26 companies in charge of the development of Libra, it is clearly the principal player.

The announcement seemed almost wilfully ignorant of the regulatory environment in which it was made. Regulators are wondering how to break up the outsized influence of big tech platforms, yet here is the worst behaving of the lot asking to be let loose in a whole new area of society.

Facebook has a storied history of doing the wrong thing by its users until it gets caught, and has done nothing to suggest it has ever learned a lesson.

It has shown contempt for accountability, by Zuckerberg's continual refusals to attend hearings with national governments that want to question him about Facebook's approach to privacy and its negative impact on democracy.

So despite the positive potential impacts and likely opportunities for fintech start-ups, it is impossible to view this as anything other than a big worry of a future privacy nightmare.
